issues.specificationExcerpt: componentPadding: 12pt (cozy) — Internal padding for code blocks, blockquotes
issues.observation: The code block's top internal padding between the 'swift' language label and the code block's top edge appears slightly less than 12pt. The label sits very close to the top boundary of the code block background.
issues.deviation: Top padding of code block may be less than the specified 12pt cozy padding, particularly above the language label.

issues.specificationExcerpt: headingSpaceAbove (H2): 32pt (spacious) — Proportional reduction from H1; still clearly a section break
issues.observation: The vertical gap above 'Heading Level 2' appears slightly less than 32pt. While there is clearly more space above H2 than below H1, the gap looks closer to 24pt (relaxed) rather than 32pt (spacious).
issues.deviation: H2 space above may be approximately 24pt instead of the specified 32pt, reducing the visual section break effect.

issues.specificationExcerpt: headingSpaceAbove (H2): 32pt (spacious) — Proportional reduction from H1; still clearly a section break
issues.observation: Same as dark theme: the vertical gap above 'Heading Level 2' appears slightly less than 32pt. The spacing appears closer to 24pt.
issues.deviation: H2 space above may be approximately 24pt instead of the specified 32pt. This is consistent across both themes, suggesting a code-level constant issue rather than a theme-specific problem.

issues.specificationExcerpt: headingSpaceAbove (H1) | 48pt (generous) | Large space above signals new major section
issues.observation: The H1 heading 'Calibration Heading One' appears at the top of the document with approximately 32pt of space above it from the window content area, which corresponds to the windowTopInset rather than the headingSpaceAbove value.
issues.deviation: Since H1 is the first element, the space above it is governed by windowTopInset (32pt spacious) rather than headingSpaceAbove (48pt generous). This is correct behavior for the first element in the document. However, the total visual space from the window chrome to the H1 text baseline appears to be around 32pt, which may feel tight for a major heading at the document start.

issues.specificationExcerpt: componentPadding | 12pt (cozy) | Internal padding for code blocks, blockquotes
issues.observation: The code block displays a language label 'swift' as separate unstyled text positioned above the main code content. The label appears as a small, low-contrast text element that is visually disconnected from the code block body.
issues.deviation: The language label 'swift' appears as a standalone text element above the code block rather than being integrated into the code block's visual container. This creates an ambiguous visual relationship between the label and the code block content.

issues.specificationExcerpt: componentPadding | 12pt (cozy) | Internal padding for code blocks, blockquotes
issues.observation: Same as dark theme: the code block language label 'swift' appears as separate unstyled text above the code content in the light theme.
issues.deviation: The language label rendering is consistent across themes but in both cases appears as a disconnected text element rather than an integrated part of the code block container.

issues.specificationExcerpt: Mermaid blocks display three possible states: 1. Loading: a spinner/progress indicator while the diagram renders 2. Success: the rendered diagram image displayed inline in the document 3. Error: a warning icon and error message if rendering fails
issues.observation: The mermaid diagram areas show only tiny placeholder elements (small squares) where full diagrams should be rendered. No flowchart, sequence, class, or state diagrams are visible in the document. The areas between headings and their following sections contain minimal content where rendered diagrams should appear.
issues.deviation: Mermaid diagrams are not rendering as inline images. Instead of showing rendered SVG diagrams (flowchart, sequence, class, state), only small placeholder indicators appear. The expected rendered diagram content is entirely missing from the document.

issues.specificationExcerpt: Mermaid blocks display three possible states: 1. Loading: a spinner/progress indicator while the diagram renders 2. Success: the rendered diagram image displayed inline in the document 3. Error: a warning icon and error message if rendering fails
issues.observation: Same as the dark theme: mermaid diagram areas show only tiny placeholder elements where full diagrams should be rendered. No actual diagram content is visible.
issues.deviation: Mermaid diagrams are not rendering in the light theme either. The FR-4 success state (rendered diagram image displayed inline) is not achieved. Small placeholder squares appear instead of rendered diagrams.

issues.specificationExcerpt: Five diagram types are supported: 1. Flowchart: directed graphs with nodes and edges 2. Sequence: interaction diagrams with participants and messages 3. State: state machine diagrams with states and transitions 4. Class: UML class diagrams with classes and relationships 5. ER (Entity-Relationship): database relationship diagrams
issues.observation: The document contains sections for Flowchart, Sequence Diagram, and Class Diagram (at minimum), but none of these diagram types are rendered visually. Only section headings and descriptive text are visible.
issues.deviation: None of the supported diagram types (flowchart, sequence, class, state) are rendering. The fixture is designed to test these diagram types but the rendering pipeline appears to produce no visible output.

issues.specificationExcerpt: Diagram containers use theme-appropriate colors: Container background: backgroundSecondary from the active theme
issues.observation: No diagram containers with distinct backgrounds are visible. The small placeholder elements do not show a backgroundSecondary container treatment.
issues.deviation: Cannot verify FR-7 compliance because diagram containers are not rendering. The expected distinct background for diagram containers is absent since diagrams themselves are not displayed.

issues.specificationExcerpt: Code block background: slightly lighter than document background (Solarized base02)
issues.observation: The HTML comment block at the top of the document renders as a visible code block with a slightly lighter background than the document base. The code block background appears to be Solarized base02, which is correct. However, the raw HTML comment text is rendered as visible content rather than being hidden.
issues.deviation: The HTML comment (<!-- ... -->) is rendered as visible text within a code-block-styled region. While this may be intentional for this test fixture (the comment contains fixture metadata), if this were a real document, raw HTML comments should not be visible. This is likely fixture-specific and not a real issue.

issues.specificationExcerpt: A language label is displayed above the code block when a language tag is present in the Markdown fence.
issues.observation: The code block under 'Keywords' shows 'swift' text at the top of the code block, followed by 'import Foundation' and 'struct Example {}'. The 'swift' text appears to serve as the language label but it is rendered inside the code block area in the same monospaced font as the code content, rather than as a distinct label element above/outside the code block.
issues.deviation: The language label 'swift' appears to be rendered inline within the code block content area rather than as a visually distinct label above the code block. It should be rendered as a separate label element (typically smaller, possibly in a different font or with different styling) to clearly distinguish it from the code content.

issues.specificationExcerpt: A language label is displayed above the code block when a language tag is present in the Markdown fence.
issues.observation: Same as ISS-002: the 'swift' language label in the light theme also appears inline within the code block content rather than as a distinct label element.
issues.deviation: The language label 'swift' is rendered inline within the code block rather than as a visually distinct label above the code block. This is consistent across both themes, indicating a systematic styling issue rather than a theme-specific problem.

issues.specificationExcerpt: Swift code blocks are tokenized and rendered with colored text using the theme's syntax color palette. Each token type maps to a specific color from SyntaxColors.
issues.observation: In the Keywords code block under the dark theme, the Swift code ('import Foundation', 'struct Example {}') appears to have some syntax coloring applied — 'import' and 'struct' appear in a different color from 'Foundation' and 'Example'. However, at the resolution visible in the screenshot, it is difficult to confirm that all nine token types are distinctly colored.
issues.deviation: Syntax highlighting appears to be partially working — keywords and types show different colors. Cannot confirm full nine-token-type differentiation from this viewport alone, but the basic keyword/type distinction is present.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The overall rendering quality in the dark theme is excellent. The Solarized Dark palette is applied consistently across all elements. Heading hierarchy is clearly distinguishable with progressive size reduction. Code blocks have a pleasingly distinct background with readable syntax highlighting. The document feels well-framed with appropriate margins.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Meets the charter's standard of 'obsessive attention to sensory detail.' The composition feels polished and intentional, suitable for daily-driver use by an aesthetically-minded developer.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The light theme rendering is equally well-executed. The Solarized Light cream background provides comfortable reading. Code blocks have appropriate visual distinction with a slightly darker background. Text contrast is good throughout. The overall feel mirrors the quality of the dark theme.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Meets the charter's design philosophy. Light theme feels like a first-class citizen alongside the dark theme rather than an afterthought. Both themes provide a polished reading experience.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The heading spacing from H4 through H6 becomes quite compressed — H4, H5, and H6 appear visually close together with diminishing differentiation. While the PRD only specifies spacing for H1-H3, the visual progression from H3 onward loses the clear hierarchical rhythm established by the top-level headings.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The H4-H6 range could benefit from defined spacing constants to maintain the spatial rhythm established by H1-H3. Currently the compressed spacing at the lower heading levels slightly undermines the otherwise excellent spatial design. This is a design gap rather than a compliance issue.

qualitativeFindings.observation: Cross-theme consistency is excellent. The spatial layout, heading sizes, margins, code block dimensions, and overall document structure are identical between dark and light themes. Only colors change — the geometry is preserved perfectly.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: This is a positive signal for implementation quality. Theme switching preserves the spatial design language, meaning the spacing system is properly abstracted from the color system.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The overall document layout demonstrates clear heading hierarchy with H1 > H2 > H3 in both size and weight. Spacing between headings and their following content shows the correct asymmetric pattern (more space above, less below), creating strong visual binding between headings and their content per Gestalt proximity principles.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The spatial rhythm is well-executed. The heading hierarchy is immediately legible and the vertical spacing creates a natural reading flow. This meets the charter's standard of intentional, polished design.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The paragraph-to-paragraph spacing between 'This is the first measurement paragraph.' and 'This is the second measurement paragraph.' is consistent and visually rhythmic. The spacing between consecutive body paragraphs is clearly less than the heading-above spacing, establishing a clear typographic hierarchy.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Paragraph spacing rhythm is excellent. The consistent inter-paragraph gaps create the steady vertical rhythm that makes long-form reading comfortable. This is daily-driver quality.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The light theme rendering maintains identical spatial layout to the dark theme. All heading sizes, spacing values, margins, and content positioning appear consistent across themes. The Solarized Light palette is correctly applied with a warm cream background and dark text.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Cross-theme consistency is strong. The light theme feels equally polished and intentional as the dark theme. Color choices are appropriate Solarized Light values. The warm background provides comfortable reading contrast.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The blockquote 'Blockquote for padding measurement.' is rendered with left indentation but no clearly visible left border decoration in the dark theme. Blockquotes traditionally use a vertical bar or border on the left edge to visually distinguish them from regular indented content.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The blockquote may benefit from a more prominent left-edge visual indicator (such as a colored vertical bar) to clearly distinguish it from other indented content. Without a visible border, the blockquote's visual identity relies solely on indentation, which could be confused with nested list content. However, the padding and indentation values themselves appear appropriate.

qualitativeFindings.observation: Document margins on both left and right sides provide generous whitespace framing. Content does not extend to the full window width, suggesting the contentMaxWidth constraint (~680pt) is being respected. The overall composition has a centered, well-framed appearance.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The document margins and content width create a comfortable reading measure. The whitespace framing gives the content room to breathe, consistent with the charter's emphasis on obsessive attention to sensory detail. This feels like a well-designed reading experience.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The HTML comment block at the top of the document is rendered as visible content in a code-block-like container, showing fixture metadata and expected rendering characteristics. This implementation detail is visible to users.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The HTML comment block containing test fixture metadata is rendered as visible content rather than being hidden. While this is a test fixture, the comment rendering behavior suggests HTML comments in markdown may not be suppressed, which could affect real-world documents with HTML comments. The code block treatment with distinct background is appropriate if this is intentional rendering of the comment syntax.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The document structure (headings, paragraphs, spacing) for the non-diagram text content appears well-composed. Heading hierarchy is clear, spacing between sections is consistent, and the Solarized Dark theme colors are cohesive.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Despite the missing diagrams, the text layout and typographic treatment meet the charter's standard of polished design. Heading sizes show clear hierarchy, spacing creates good visual grouping, and the color palette is consistently Solarized Dark.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The Solarized Light theme version shows identical layout structure to the Dark version, with consistent spacing between elements across both themes.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Theme-independent spacing consistency is maintained between dark and light variants. The layout structure, heading sizes, and inter-element spacing appear identical across themes, which is correct behavior. The light theme color palette is cohesive and distinctly Solarized Light.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The Solarized Dark theme presents a cohesive, visually harmonious appearance. The background is the correct dark blue-gray of Solarized base03. Text contrast is strong and readable. Code blocks have a distinct but harmonious slightly-lighter background. The heading 'Syntax Token Reference' uses a larger font with good visual hierarchy. The overall impression is of a well-crafted dark theme.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The dark theme meets the charter's standard of intentional design. The color palette is consistent Solarized throughout, with no stray non-Solarized colors visible. The document feels comfortable for reading and conveys a polished, native Mac application aesthetic.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The Solarized Light theme presents a warm, comfortable reading experience. The background is the correct warm off-white of Solarized base3. Text is dark gray (base00) with strong contrast. Code blocks have a subtly darker cream/tan background (base2) that is distinct yet harmonious. Heading hierarchy is clear with appropriate sizing.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The light theme is equally polished as the dark theme. The warm Solarized palette creates a comfortable, paper-like reading experience. All visible colors belong to the Solarized Light family. The composition feels intentional and professional.

qualitativeFindings.observation: Comparing both theme screenshots, the layout structure, spacing, and element positioning appear identical. Only colors change between dark and light themes. Headings occupy the same relative positions, code blocks have the same dimensions, and text spacing is consistent.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: Cross-theme layout consistency is excellent, meeting the specification that 'only colors change' between themes. This indicates a well-architected theme system where layout is decoupled from color theming.

qualitativeFindings.observation: The vertical spacing between the heading 'Syntax Token Reference' and its following content appears well-proportioned. The heading has more space above it than below it, creating good Gestalt proximity binding between the heading and its content. The sub-heading 'Keywords' also follows this pattern.
qualitativeFindings.assessment: The spatial rhythm demonstrates attention to typographic detail. Heading-to-content binding is correct, creating a natural reading flow. This meets the charter's standard for obsessive attention to sensory detail in the spatial dimension.
